items.content_html:
Summary

Adds browser support information for using format("*-variations") in the src property of the @font-face rule. Also rewords the format(keyword) entry for brevity and symmetry.

I was unsure what to do about mobile browsers for which I can't identify the initial version that supports the feature...

Test results and supporting details

Used information from Can I Use and confirmed in Browserstack with this test case, reproduced below:

font-face-src.html 
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
	<meta charset="utf-8">
	<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1">
	<title>@font-face/src syntax test</title>

	<style type='text/css'>
		/*
			AdobeBlank font licensed under OFL 1.1.
			A copy of the license can be consulted here:

			https://github.com/adobe-fonts/adobe-blank/blob/master/LICENSE.txt
		 */
		@font-face {
    font-family: AdobeBlank;
    src:
    url("data:font/opentype;base64,");
}

		/*
			The font declarations below used a subset of the Zilla Slab font,
			generated with the Embedded Google Fonts tool:

			https://amio.github.io/embedded-google-fonts/

			The original Zilla Slab font is licensed under OFL 1.1. 
			A copy of the license can be consulted here: 

			https://github.com/mozilla/zilla-slab/blob/master/LICENSE
		*/
		@font-face {
			font-family: woff2;
			src: url('data:font/woff2;base64,') format('woff2');
		}

		@font-face {
			font-family: woff2-kw;
			src: url('data:font/woff2;base64,') format(woff2);
		}

		@font-face {
			font-family: woff2-variations;
			src: url('data:font/woff2;base64,') format('woff2-variations');
		}

		@font-face {
			font-family: woff2-variations-kw;
			src: url('data:font/woff2;base64,') format(woff2-variations);
		}

		@font-face {
			font-family: woff2-supports-variations;
			src: url('data:font/woff2;base64,') format('woff2 supports variations');
		}

		@font-face {
			font-family: woff2-supports-variations-kw;
			src: url('data:font/woff2;base64,') format(woff2 supports variations);
		}

		@font-face {
			font-family: woff2-format-technology;
			src: url('data:font/woff2;base64,') format('woff2') technology('variations');
		}

		@font-face {
			font-family: woff2-format-technology-kw;
			src: url('data:font/woff2;base64,') format('woff2') technology(variations);
		}

		@font-face {
			font-family: woff2-format-technology-kw2;
			src: url('data:font/woff2;base64,') format(woff2) technology(variations);
		}

		body {
			max-width: 50em;
			margin: 0 auto;
		}

		dd {
			font-family: var(--font), AdobeBlank;
			font-size: 2em;
			color: green;
			margin: 0;
		}

		dl > * {
			display: flex;
			align-items: center;
		}

	</style>
</head>
<body>
	<h1><code>@font-face/src</code> syntax test</h1>
	<dl>
		<div>
			<dt><code>format('woff2')</code></dt>
			<dd style='--font: woff2'>✓</dd>
		</div>

		<div>
			<dt><code>format(woff2)</code></dt>
			<dd style='--font: woff2-kw'>✓</dd>
		</div>
		<div>
			<dt><code>format('woff2-variations')</code></dt>
			<dd style='--font: woff2-variations'>✓</dd>
		</div>
		<div>
			<dt><code>format(woff2-variations)</code></dt>
			<dd style='--font: woff2-variations-kw'>✓</dd>
		</div>
		<div>
			<dt><code>format('woff2 supports variations')</code></dt>
			<dd style='--font: woff2-supports-variations'>✓</dd>
		</div>
		<div>
			<dt><code>format(woff2 supports variations)</code></dt>
			<dd style='--font: woff2-supports-variations-kw'>✓</dd>
		</div>
		<div>
			<dt><code>format('woff2') technology('variations')</code></dt>
			<dd style='--font: woff2-format-technology'>✓</dd>
		</div>
		<div>
			<dt><code>format('woff2') technology(variations)</code></dt>
			<dd style='--font: woff2-format-technology-kw'>✓</dd>
		</div>

		<div>
			<dt><code>format(woff2) technology(variations)</code></dt>
			<dd style='--font: woff2-format-technology-kw2'>✓</dd>
		</div>
	</dl>
</body>
</html>

Related issues

Fixes #13827.
items.title: css.at-rules.font-face.src: add browser support for format("*-variations")

items.content_html:
Summary

Add a note of URL Constructor in old Edge to specify a special behaviour.

Test results and supporting details

// Chrome, Firefox, Node, New Edge
new URL('', 'http://www.test.com?sid=1').searchParams.get('sid'); // => "1"
// Old Edge
new URL('', 'http://www.test.com?sid=1').searchParams.get('sid'); // => null
items.title: Add a note of URL Constructor in old Edge

items.content_html: Update per new events guideline: https://github.com/mdn/browser-compat-data/blob/main/docs/data-guidelines.md#dom-events-eventname_event
items.title: WakeLockSentinel: onrelease -> release_event

items.content_html:
Support added for Navigator.canShare() in FF96 according to this bug: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1666203

Note:

  • It is fairly certain this would still be behind a preference, but I am checking just in case.
  • It is fairly certain this text cannot be shared, but I am checking just in case.
  • It is 100% certain that files can still not be shared.
items.title: FF96 supports Navigator.canShare()

items.content_html:
They Eyedropper API requires a secure context, as documented in the spec: https://wicg.github.io/eyedropper-api/#idl-index

Anecdotally, this requirement was added in Chrome 96: mdn/content#10837. Hence this PR. I can't find confirmation online so have requested verification.
items.title: Eyedropper API requires secure context

items.content_html:
Summary

As of Chrome 98 the BarcodeDetector interface will be supported on all desktop platforms.

The implementation on these platforms is not part of the Chromium project and so support in other Chromium-based browsers is unchanged.

Test results and supporting details

https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/3290206

Related issues

Fixes #13752.
items.title: Update supported platforms for BarcodeDetector in Chrome

items.content_html: See #13595 for the proposed guideline.
items.title: WebSocket: Single event entries

items.content_html:
Second attempt to merge XHR events to single entries.
See #13598 (comment) for context

Here I'm removing XMLHttpRequestEventTarget entirely and events are installed on XMLHttpRequest and XMLHttpRequestUpload. I'm assuming same compat data, but I think @foolip assumes they are different. Happy to adjust.
items.title: XHR API: Single event entries / remove XMLHttpRequestEventTarget

items.content_html:
Summary

line_breaks compability was fixed in firefox 59 (bug)
items.title: Update line_breaks Firefox compability

items.content_html:
Following on from #13627 this looks at the rest of the API.
Most of the interfaces have at least two implementations, and so are, by definition, not experimental. There are a few questions for some of them though:

  • SpeechRecognitionAlternative - not experimental - more than two implementations
  • SpeechRecognitionResult - not experimental - more than two implementations
  • SpeechRecognitionResultList - not experimental - more than two implementations
  • SpeechSynthesis - not experimental - more than two implementations
  • SpeechSynthesisErrorEvent - not experimental - more than two implementations
  • SpeechSynthesisVoice - not experimental - more than two implementations

Possible additional changes, pending questions:

  • SpeechRecognition, SpeechRecognitionEvent, SpeechGrammar, SpeechGrammarList "implemented with the vendor prefix: webkit" in chrome and variants. These are supported in more than one browser, but with this caveat, is this "experimental"?
  • SpeechRecognition, SpeechRecognitionAlternative, SpeechRecognitionResult, SpeechRecognitionResultList, and a bunch of others are marked as false for Opera and OperaAndroid . Chrome went in blink 33, which corresponds to Opera 20. Is this likely an error? I plan on ignoring for now.
items.title: Speech API is not (mosty) experimental

items.content_html:
To include additional limitation on triggering permissions.request() in Firefox for Android

Summary

Add clarification that trying to call permissions.request from a browserAction.onClicked event in Firefox for Android will throw an error, despite it being a valid user interaction.

Test results and supporting details

See mozilla-mobile/fenix#22348

Related issues

See mozilla-mobile/fenix#22348
items.title: Firefox for Android permissions.request can't be triggered by browserAction.onClicked

items.content_html:
I believe that error, languagechange, offline and online would be global events.
An idea could be to put them in the _globals folders and remove them from the mixins GlobalEventHandlers and WindowEventHandlers and other places where they currently appear.

cc @foolip for feedback
items.title: Global events: error, languagechange, offline, online

items.content_html: See #13595 for the proposed guideline.
items.title: XRSession: Use single entry for events

items.content_html:
Summary

Over in mdn/content#10539 I'm proposing to add MDN documentation for the new Window Controls Overlay PWA feature. One part of this feature is the navigator.windowControlsOverlay API. So in order to document it in MDN, we need its compat data here on this repo.

Test results and supporting details

The Window Controls Overlay feature is documented here: https://web.dev/window-controls-overlay/ and here https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-edge/progressive-web-apps-chromium/how-to/window-controls-overlay
and its current spec is on the WICG repo here: https://wicg.github.io/window-controls-overlay/
It was implemented in Chromium in 93 (available as origin trial then).
items.title: Compat data for navigator.windowControlsOverlay API

items.content_html:
Summary

Over in mdn/content#10539 I'm proposing to add MDN documentation for the new Window Controls Overlay PWA feature. One part of this feature is the display_override manifest member. So in order to document it in MDN, we need its compat data here on this repo.

Test results and supporting details

The Window Controls Overlay feature is documented here: https://web.dev/window-controls-overlay/ and here https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-edge/progressive-web-apps-chromium/how-to/window-controls-overlay
and its current spec is on the WICG repo here: https://wicg.github.io/window-controls-overlay/#addition-of-window-controls-overlay-to-the-manifest
It was implemented in Chromium in 93 (available as origin trial then).
items.title: Adding the display_override manifest member compat data
